qas.question: William Atwood suggested that Chopin's music wasn't purposely patriotic but what?
A modern commentator, William Atwood, feels Poles not only sought solace in Chopin's music but also found them a source of strength as they continued to fight for what?

context: A reconciliation of these views is suggested by William Atwood: "Undoubtedly [Chopin's] use of traditional musical forms like the polonaise and mazurka roused nationalistic sentiments and a sense of cohesiveness amongst those Poles scattered across <a2_0>Europe and the New World<a2_0/> ... While some sought solace in [them], others found them a source of strength in their continuing struggle for <a1_0>freedom<a1_0/>. Although Chopin's music undoubtedly came to him <a0_0>intuitive<a0_0/>ly rather than through any conscious patriotic design, it served all the same to symbolize the will of the Polish people ..."
